fields.description: Quartz Scheduler 2.0 brings a number of improvements but also makes breaking API changes. If some products need to upgrade we should decide a strategy that lets Crowd run against the 1.x and 2.x versions, possibly by going through SAL. SAL may need changes to support Crowd's scheduling requirements.
fields.summary: Upgrade Quartz Scheduler to 2.2

fields.description:
This issue was discovered while investigating an issue where Confluence 4.1.2 (using a Crowd 2.3.2/Embedded Crowd 1.3.3 stack) would fail to synchronize properly with a standalone Crowd 2.4.0.

The standalone Crowd server had multiple LDAP directories. Some usernames were found in more than one directory. This, in itself, was fine. However, some usernames used different capitalizations in different directories (i.e. one directory having a user with a username of "foo.bar", and another directory having a user with a username of "Foo.Bar").

The effect of this, was that these users would be synchronized *every* time Confluence and Crowd synchronized. It would work every second time, and fail every second time. The failure manifested as logged exceptions caused by uniqueness constraint violations in the database bubbled up through Hibernate to the app. The user-visible effect was that the synchronization failed silently every second time.

It seems some parts of the Crowd stack use case-insensitive comparison for usernames, and some use case-sensitive.
fields.summary: Usernames with different capitalizations in different directories breaks synchronization

fields.description:
The application list on http://$cwd_server/crowd/console/secure/application/addapplicationdetails.action lists 
* Jira
* Confluence
* Bamboo
* Crucible
* Fisheye
* Generic Application

Stash is not among the list of applications to choose. There is a wiki page for Crowd/Stash integration (detailed in the description of STASH-2547), but the page does not specify which application type to use. 

(!) The component list for the Crowd project does not even list Stash, so I had to use the generic "Integration/Connectors" component as opposed to one with the specific Atlassian Product (such as "Integration - Stash") when opening this ticket.
fields.summary: Add Stash to the Application Type drop-down list

fields.description:
Currently the User object only provides getName() which is the case-preserving value.

This value is not appropriate to be stored as a foreign-key as it can change over time (eg from "jennyw" to "JennyW")

Crowd should supply a case-sensitive getKey() method (or similar) on User to make dealing with foreign keys easier.
fields.summary: Embedded Crowd should make it easier and more efficient to deal with the case-insensitive case-preserving nature of usernames

Crowd builds with support for Seraph 2.1, 2.2 and 2.5. All current Atlassian applications are using 2.5: no future application will be using 2.1 or 2.2.

fields.description:
The page [Configuring Confluence for NTLM SSO|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+Confluence+for+NTLM+SSO] makes reference to a Confluence MTLM Plugin, but all links to the plugin are broken.

The most similar plugin I found was [Confluence NTLM Authenticator|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.jnj.confluence.ntlmauth] but last update is from 2009 and the latest supported Confluence version is 2.10.4.

I found this plugin, [Single-Sign-on (SSO) Authenticator for Active Directory (via Kerberos)|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/KRBROS] that seems to provide the same functionality, but it uses Kerberos rather than NTLM. The documentation needs to be updated.
fields.summary: Reference to deprecated plugin

fields.description:
h3.Error:
{noformat}
 11:22:42,426 QuartzWorker-1 WARN ServiceRunner [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] remote username [ KaaaE ] casing differs from local username [ kaaae ]. User details will be kept updated, but the username cannot be updated
 11:22:42,426 QuartzWorker-1 WARN ServiceRunner [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] remote username [ NPtest ] casing differs from local username [ nptest ]. User details will be kept updated, but the username cannot be updated
 11:22:42,426 QuartzWorker-1 WARN ServiceRunner [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] remote username [ PRconf ] casing differs from local username [ prconf ]. User details will be kept updated, but the username cannot be updated
 11:22:42,427 QuartzWorker-1 WARN ServiceRunner [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] remote username [ RaSh ] casing
{noformat}

h3.Steps to Reproduce:

1) Create a Crowd internal directory
2) Create a user in that directory named 'dbtte'
3) Add that user to the 'jira-users' group
4) Confirm that that user can log in to JIRA, assign them some issues, etc
5) Connect Crowd to an LDAP directory as a delegated auth directory
6) Create a user 'DBtte' in LDAP
7) Authenticate as the LDAP user via JIRA/Crowd
8) Create a 'jira-users' group for the LDAP directory
9) Add the 'DBtte' LDAP user to 'jira-users'
10) Delete the 'dbtte' internal user
11) Attempt to log in to Crowd

h3. Other steps to reproduce (Crowd Internal Directory only)
# Create a user in Crowd which will be available to the Confluence application using the following details
#- Email Address: CamelCaseTC1@test.test
#- Active: Checked
#- Username: CamelCaseTC1
#- FirstName: CamelCaseTC1
#- LastName: CamelCaseTC1
#- Groups: Group1, Group2, Group3
# Within Confluence, force a Crowd Directory Sync & confirm that the user exists with the correct group memberships
# Back in Crowd, delete the previous user
# Create a user in Crowd which will be available to the Confluence application using the following details, but with the username.tolower() & an additional group membership
#- Email Address: CamelCaseTC1@test.test
#- Active: Checked
#- Username: camelcasetc1
#- FirstName: CamelCaseTC1
#- LastName: CamelCaseTC1
#- Groups: Group1, Group2, Group3, Group4
# Within Confluence, force a Crowd Directory Sync (or two) & wait for the hibernate SQL exception to appear

h3.Workarounds
# Set all users and groups that experience this issue back to the original casing, specified in 'local username' or 'local groupname'.
# Disable the directory by unticking 'Active'. Create a new directory, copying the settings of the existing directory, and sync that. When you're satisfied that everything has come across correctly and you will not be missing any users/groups/memberships, remove the old directory.
fields.summary: Mixed case with LDAP, couldn't synchronize users and groups

fields.description: Currently, a crowd-managed application has no way of determining if it will be able to add users through crowd - if the application thinks it has write access, but every directory associated with that application is read only, the create will fail. To avoid this, crowd should publish (via its REST API) whether canAddUser is true for an application. This will allow smarter handling on the application side, including disabling user management and showing helpful error messages.
fields.summary: Publish and update remote crowd directory read/write permissions

fields.description: Currently, the only way a product can check if a directory is writable is to duplicate a sizable piece of logic from ApplicationServiceGeneric. This code should be made available from the CrowdService via a method canAddUser(), so that host products can more easily disable relevant functionality and display helpful messages (such as "you can't add users here. Go to Directory X instead") in their user management screens.
fields.summary: Expose check for if there are any directories with create user permission

fields.description: When syncing an LDAP directory with Active Directory using incremental sync, user and group checks on periodic sync will properly respect the uSNChanged attribute and only make needed changes.  However, even if {{AbstractCacheRefresher.synchroniseMemberships()}} returns an empty list, the connector will still query LDAP for all of the groups and check memberships as per a full sync, which can be very expensive in large ADs that depend on incremental syncs for performance.
fields.summary: LDAP connector using Incremental Sync still syncs all memberships

fields.description:
{{CrowdUserDetailsServiceImpl#getAuthorities}} tests group membership by getting all of a user's memberships ({{getMemberships}}) rather than testing with individual calls to {{isMember}}. This can require fetching all memberships for the application, which can be slow.

Investigate the impact of switching to {{isMember}} when there are large numbers of memberships configured.
fields.summary: Improve performance of Crowd console and Spring Security integration with large numbers of memberships
UpgradeTask426 fails with large numbers of users
Allow forcing SSLv3 for LDAPS connections

fields.description:
If you change the case of a username in LDAP, the next time the directory syncs, Crowd will throw this error about a duplicate entry in the cwd_membership table, and the user will disappear from the directory cache:
{code}
2012-05-25 18:07:26,433 scheduler_Worker-1 ERROR [org.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter] Batch entry 0 insert into cwd_membership (parent_id, child_id, membership_type, group_type, parent_name, lower_parent_name, child_name, lower_child_name, directory_id, id) values ('720898', '65545', 'GROUP_USER', 'GROUP', 'Durarara', 'durarara', 'celty', 'celty', '32770', '786433') was aborted.  Call getNextException to see the cause.
2012-05-25 18:07:26,433 scheduler_Worker-1 WARN [org.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter] SQL Error: 0, SQLState: 23505
2012-05-25 18:07:26,433 scheduler_Worker-1 ERROR [org.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter] ERROR: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "cwd_membership_parent_id_key"
2012-05-25 18:07:26,434 scheduler_Worker-1 ERROR [hibernate.event.def.AbstractFlushingEventListener] Could not synchronize database state with session
org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException: Could not execute JDBC batch update
        at org.hibernate.exception.SQLStateConverter.convert(SQLStateConverter.java:71)
        at org.hibernate.exception.JDBCExceptionHelper.convert(JDBCExceptionHelper.java:43)
        at org.hibernate.jdbc.AbstractBatcher.executeBatch(AbstractBatcher.java:254)
{code}

In this example, user 'celty' was changed to user 'CeltY' when the error occurred.

The next time the directory syncs, the username will not exist in the database, so they will be added with the new casing of the username, however, there is no error in the UI or indication that this happened, so to the end user, it simply appears as failed logins to the applications backed by Crowd.
fields.summary: Duplicate error when username case is changed in LDAP and user disappears from the directory

fields.description:
In Administration > General settings, when we try to configure Crowd in SSO mode for our entire *.paris-web.fr domain with the value ".paris-web.fr" (as documented), the form returns with the following error: "The domain is invalid".

But ".paris-web.fr" is a perfectly valid domain.

So far our workaround was to feed this value directly into the domain property inside cwd_property.
fields.summary: Syntax validation for SSO Domain rejects perfectly valid domain

fields.description:
I recently accidentally exceeded my license count, and was surprised when I tried to access Crowd and was presented with the "license count exceeded" window.

Now, most helpful would be to allow Crowd admins to log in to Crowd directly (e.g. only disallow logins for regular users and connected apps), but in the absence of that, I would at least recommend improving the text on that screen.

I had to hunt around for a while before I figured out that (a) there was no way past to screen so I could just go delete some users (b) that the correct approach was to install a temporary evaluation license, fix the issue, then restore my paid license.

Something simple like:

"If you'd like to correct the issue by removing or disabling some users, temporarily install an evaluation license, make the required changes, and then restore your paid license."
fields.summary: Improve the explanatory text on the "License exceeded" page

fields.description:
When viewing a user, on the "Attributes" tab, there are "Attribute:" and "Value:" fields:

!crowdbug.png!

Filling in "Attribute" and "Value" and pressing enter does not cause the attribute to be added, as one would expect. Instead the "Update" action is triggered, which just causes a page refresh.
fields.summary: User attributes not added when enter pressed

fields.description:
Are timeouts used in all Crowd Clients ?

I can see that in RestExecutor, we use a default of 5seconds for the ConnectionTimeout. Which:
bq. Sets the timeout until a connection is established.

However, it looks like use an infinite _Socket Timeout_.

bq. socket timeout (SO_TIMEOUT) in milliseconds which is the timeout for waiting for data. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout.

So, if a connection is established and then crowd hangs, or goes down, will the client receive a connection closed, and return control to the app, or will it hang infinitely?

It appears to describe the behaviour we saw on eac/crucible today where a crowd-upgrade caused FishEye/Crucible to hang for at least 1 hour.
fields.summary: What timeout strategies are used by crowd-client?

fields.description:
The error sent to SOAP clients only includes the message of the exception, not the cause. Since around 2.1, when exceptions are wrapped in {{SpringLDAPConnector}} the message is just the username.

The wrapped exceptions should include the underlying message as part of the text so it's visible to SOAP clients.
fields.summary: Include underlying exception from LDAP directory in authentication failures

fields.description: When you attempt to login to an OpenID web app using your OpenID URL such as  http://localhost:8095/openidserver/users/<USERNAME>, the page will then redirect you to your OpenIDServer, which will request for your OpenID username and password. Considering that the username is already provided in the OpenID URL, it would be nice if the username field would have been entered automatically (by fetching the value from the URL).
fields.summary: Allow username field to be entered automatically based on an OpenID URL

fields.description:
When importing a huge amount of users and its membership, the {{CSV}} importer function did not provide us a good information if the import was failing.

It would be a great idea if Atlassian can improve it with the following point

# Split it in two parts
#* One users importer and one groups importer, so that in a first run the users can be imported
#* And later in one and more subsequent runs the group relations could be setup or updated.
# Return the successful/failed records of a run into two new csv files so the user can have a look at it and correct or refine for the next import. 

That would be a smart logic I think.
fields.summary: CSV importer feature need to be improve

fields.description:
h3.Problem
There is a problem when installing Crowd as a service in 64bit. Problems may be similar to this:

* [Problem Installing...|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/Problems+Installing+Confluence+as+a+Service+on+Windows+64bit] (this is a Confluence KB, but works equally to Crowd)

When this is fixed, and Crowd is successfully installed as Service, it will load and then fail with this message on the logs:
{code}
2012-04-17 12:41:16,508 main INFO [com.atlassian.crowd.startup] Starting Crowd Server, Version: 2.4.0 (Build:#562 - 02-01-2012) 
2012-04-17 12:41:16,588 main INFO [ContainerBase.[Catalina].[localhost].[/crowd]] org.tuckey.web.filters.urlrewrite.UrlRewriteFilter INFO: loaded (conf ok)
2012-04-17 12:41:44,999 http-8095-2 INFO [service.soap.client.SecurityServerClientImpl] Existing application token is null, authenticating ...
{code}

There is no Workaround.
fields.summary: Cannot run Crowd as Service, 64bit, Existing application token is null, authenticating ...

fields.description:
This might better belong in JIRA but as it affects both JIRA and Confluence I suspect it may be related to Crowd implementation in these products.


If you create the following user setup:
* Crowd - brendan.haire@atlassian.com
* JIRA - bhaire2

Then you enable SSO and hook up Crowd and JIRA and alias brendan.haire@atlassian to be bhaire2 in JIRA you are able to login to Crowd and then have SSO across to JIRA.

fields.description: bcrypt provides an algorithm that requires extensive, tunable work to test a password, making it resistant to brute-force password cracking. Crowd should include it.
fields.summary: Support bcrypt password encoding

fields.description:
When querying across directories, Crowd currently queries them individually and then aggregates in-memory.

When all directories are stored locally, either as local directories or cached remote, aggregating across directories can happen directly in the database for a performance increase.
fields.summary: Use a single query for cross-directory searches when all directories are local

fields.description: Setup for LDAP Delegated Authentication Directory requires User Group Attribute value but our LDAP schema does not have anything corresponding to a memberOf attribute. This means that I can't setup LDAP auth and automatic user creation in Crowd.
fields.summary: Setup for LDAP Delegated Authentication Directory requires User Group Attribute value

fields.description:
The ApplicationServiceGeneric search methods try to fetch (offset + maxResults) results from each directory, but they will stop querying the underlying directories when then have {{maxResults}} results. They should only return when they have at least offset + maxResults.

For example, querying with a start index of 10 and max results of 5, if the first directory contained six users we would decide we had more than five, never query the second directory, but then throw those six users away because they come before the start index.

This is only an issue when paging. Queries for ALL_RESULTS are unaffected.

CWD-2748 fixed this for {{searchUsers}}, but it's still an issue for {{searchGroups}}, {{searchDirectGroupRelationships}} and {{searchNestedGroupRelationships}}.
fields.summary: ApplicationServiceGeneric search methods may return too few results when paging
Unable to set attribute on group using REST API

fields.description:
authenticate(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest request, javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse response, java.lang.String username, java.lang.String password)

authenticateWithoutValidatingPassword does not seem to do this.

http://docs.atlassian.com/crowd/latest/com/atlassian/crowd/integration/http/CrowdHttpAuthenticator.html

fields.description:
ApplicationServiceGeneric uses a locale-specific case-insensitive comparison that takes a long time when large numbers of users are returned.

([EMBCWD-885|https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/EMBCWD-885])
fields.summary: ApplicationServiceGeneric.searchUsers is slow with large numbers of users

fields.description:
Crowd's source build currently uses useReactor, so it will only include modules that were included in the same build. This means that building the source module alone won't include any source.

Fix this to disable useReactor and include the dependencies directly. As the source distribution will fail during release:prepare (because the release isn't tagged yet) make careful use of profiles to ensure this is only built during release:perform or a specific build targeting this module.
fields.summary: Don't use useReactor for the source build

fields.description: Crowd's currently using the oracle-jdbc15 JDBC drivers for testing and in the distribution. For JDK 6 we should move to ojdbc6.
fields.summary: Use ojdbc6 driver for Oracle

fields.description: Since CWD-2406 the regular and -dev bundled plugins are identical. Only build a single zip to reduce the size of the distribution.
fields.summary: Don't use a separate bundled plugin zip in dev mode

fields.description: JIRA customers have a need to move users between directories and this is currently not possible (or at best very hacky) without support in Crowd for this.
fields.summary: Add a move/copy user facility to the CrowdService to allow embedding products to move users between directories.

fields.description:
Hi,

We have Jira, Confluence, Crowd, Bamboo, Jira all running behind a reverse proxy (apache httpd). We would like to log the currently authenticated user in the logs of apache, instead of having 5 different tomcat valve logs with that information.

Would you please add this information in a response header - obviously, for simplicity, the same header name across all Atlassian apps would be welcome.

Thank you
--
Issa
fields.summary: Add authenticated user in http response headers for logging ability in reverse proxy

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability in Crowd that results from the way XML parsers are used. This vulnerability allows an attacker to:

*    Execute denial of service attacks against the Crowd server, or
*    Read all local files readable to the system user under which Crowd runs.

All versions of Crowd up to and including 2.4.0 are affected by this vulnerability. 

Full details of the severity, risks and vulnerability can be found in the *[Crowd Security Advisory 2012-05-17|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Crowd+Security+Advisory+2012-05-17]*.
fields.summary: XML Vulnerability in Crowd

fields.description:
As anyone would expect AD administration is not the same as CROWD and changing things in AD is almost always a very bureaucratic process that takes many days.

Duplicate groups should only give warnings and not stopping the synctronization. In addition to that, the number of groups with duplicate names cannot be detected at once... so if you have 100 duplicates and it takes 7 days (optimistic) to solve a duplicate group naming issue in corporate Active Directory, it could easily take *years* to setup Crowd.

fields.description:
Zipping up bundled plugins slows the build and makes it more difficult to compare releases. We should ship them as files or resources along with an index for the plugins system to load.

Additionally, the bundled plugins and dev bundled plugins are now identical, but still add another few MB to the distribution.
fields.summary: Don't deploy bundled plugins as a zip file

fields.description:
Actually I have some Atlassian apps such as JIRA, Confluence etc. All apps were using JIRA as a user management base. 
Now I've got CROWD and I've successfully moved all users from JIRA to the CROWD internal dicertory. And this is fine.
But also I have Microsoft AD, and I also have connected it as a second CROWD directory.
Now I have 2 user directoties in CROWD - internal and AD. And most of users in both directories are the same persons.
And here I've got a problem. I have a lot of issues in JIRA and pages in Confluence which were created by users from JIRA directory. And now I want to make accounts from AD and JIRA to be merged for most of the users to keep history/backlog of all the issues/pages.
So for example issue KEY-123 was created by user gogalev@me.com (from JIRA/CROWD directory). But this user has an account in my AD - Grigoriy Lev. And my goal is to let user Grigoriy Lev become a pair to user gogalev@me.com and login to JIRA/Confluence under AD account and see issue KEY-123 as my own.

Please put in on your scheduler.
fields.summary: Merging users from different directories

fields.description:
Crowd pools LDAP connections using JNDI's support. Spring LDAP offers its own connection pool implementation with several improvements, including testing connections before use:

http://static.springsource.org/spring-ldap/site/reference/html/pooling.html

Using this pool would also allow us to pool separately for different directories.
fields.summary: Use Spring LDAP's connection pooling support

fields.description:
com.atlassian.crowd.model.user.UserTemplate extends com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.api.User when it really should extend com.atlassian.crowd.model.user.User. UserTemplate has firstName and lastName as properties, yet doesn't implement the model interface.

It's mostly annoying, but if UserTemplate is what we're being decreed to use on the client end of the REST Client, implementing the embedded interface doesn't jive with what the REST Client wants.

This also applies to UserTemplateWithAttributes and UserTemplateWithCredentialAndAttributes.
fields.summary: UserTemplate implements wrong User interface

fields.description:
As describe on our Crowd documentation download page [here|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ALLDOC/Crowd+Documentation+Directory#CrowdDocumentationDirectory-downloads] the latest version that is available for download is 2.3 instead of 2.4

* [Latest Version of Downloadable Documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ALLDOC/Crowd+Documentation+Directory#CrowdDocumentationDirectory-downloads]
fields.summary: Crowd 2.4 documentation export is not available yet

fields.description:
If Crowd is connected to an Active Directory cluster it does not properly support incremental synchronization since the {{usnChanged}} attribute value is not replicated between AD servers:
{code:title=atlassian-confluence.log}
2017-08-25 00:28:51,783 ERROR [Caesium-1-3] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingDirectoryPoller] pollChanges Error occurred while refreshing the cache for directory [ 21757953 ].
com.atlassian.crowd.exception.OperationFailedException: Error looking up attributes for highestCommittedUSN
{code}
See
* [Configuring Caching for an LDAP Directory \- Notes|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+Caching+for+an+LDAP+Directory#ConfiguringCachingforanLDAPDirectory-Notes]

Crowd should be enhanced to know which server it is connected to and:
* Perform an incremental synchronization if it connects to the same server a second time concurrently
* Perform a full synchronization if it connects to a different server

See [Users are Unable to Log In Due to 'Error looking up attributes for highestCommittedUSN'|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=244352186]
fields.summary: Detect Active Directory server to handle usnChanged attribute correctly

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Create a Delegated Authentication Directory in Crowd
# Check the *Synchronize Group Memberships* checkbox in the Connector tab
# In the Configuration Tab, make sure that the *Group Description Attribute* is set to a valid attribute (that contains values) based on the [LDIF Export|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Getting+an+LDIF+Export+of+a+User+or+Group] of any LDAP groups in your LDAP directory.
# Set the Delegated Authentication Directory that you just created as the highest priority directory for your Crowd application, via {{Applications >> crowd >> Directories}}, with *Allow all to authenticate*.
# Login using any LDAP user to the Crowd Console. Then log out, and login again as the Crowd Admin. Make sure that groups that he/she is member of is pulled to Crowd ({{Crowd Console >> Groups}}). Notice that the Group description attribute is empty.

You can verify that this is working properly with a regular Connector directory by creating a Connector directory with the exact same settings as the Delegated Authentication directory that you created. Synchronize the Connector directory, and notice that the group description is not empty, as opposed to the Delegated Authentication directory.
fields.summary: Delegated Directory does not pull the Group Description Attribute

fields.description: User shows up in Crowd directory for Jira, but user says they can't log into Jira.
fields.summary: User cannot login into Jira. Jira using Crowd and user shows up in crowd
Crowd SSO can fail when x-forwarded-for contains port number

fields.description:
I recently downloaded the Crowd source distribution for version 2.4.0 via my.atlassian.com. When I extracted the archive, I discovered that it is missing the entire /atlassian-crowd directory. In previous versions (as recently as 2.3.6) this was the directory that contained the source for the application. I've checked both the .zip file and the .tar.gz file that MAC offers and neither of them have it.

I can't seem to find it anywhere else in the archive, so I'm hoping you can either point me in the right direction or get the archive files corrected.

Thanks!

(Also, version 2.4 isn't an option for the Affects Version/s field yet, so I selected unknown.)
fields.summary: Crowd Source Distribution for 2.4.0 is missing the actual source

fields.description: I want to search the Crowd Groups using the REST API. The description field is not searchable right now. Please make it searchable too.
fields.summary: Make Group description searchable through REST API

fields.description:
Crowd sets the JVM's file.encoding to UTF-8 when it runs from a script. It doesn't when it's run as a Windows service, so it picks up the platform default encoding.

It should be consistent.
fields.summary: file.encoding isn't set when Crowd runs as a service

fields.description: Crowd's startup scripts set the default character encoding to UTF-8, and the rest of Crowd assumes this has happened. We should include the character encoding in the system info page as a way of making sure this setting is as expected.
fields.summary: Show file.encoding in system info

fields.description:
Currently, the Bamboo-Crowd integration docs are a bit confusing and separated in two different spaces:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Integrating+Crowd+with+Atlassian+Bamboo
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+Crowd

We need to merge the two pages into a single one.

It seems that the reason why they are in different pages is that we still want to keep the old steps (pre-Bamboo 3.2) in the same page. Currently the new instructions were moved to the BAMBOO space.

*The ideal would be:*
1. Have the Crowd side and the Bamboo new steps in a single page located in the Crowd space.
2. The Bamboo space would link to the Crowd space page
3. The old instructions (pre-Bamboo 3.2) would be removed from the official page and placed in a separated page (currently, the newest steps are in a different page/space)
4. The SSO steps can be kept in the official page, as they are necessary for the old and new versions of Bamboo
fields.summary: Refactor Exisiting Bamboo-Crowd integration Docs

fields.description: It would be convenient for customers if we support StartTLS over LDAP.
fields.summary: Support StartTLS for LDAP Connection

fields.description:
When users are synchronised between an LDAP directory and an embedded directory in JIRA or Confluence all the attriburtes of the directory entry are retrieved only though a ver small number of attributes are actually used.  This may include attributes such as the user's photo.

This has a large performance impact during synchronisation and also during login when an individual entry is synchronised on ligin.
fields.summary: Crowd retrieves too much data when synchronising an LDAP directory.

fields.description:
This is a problem if the csv contains non-latin characters. 

I looked in the source code and crowd creates a {{new FileReader()}}. This constructor uses the platform default encoding which is usually not utf-8. We should force this to be utf-8. '

Support case here:
https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CWDSUP-6149
fields.summary: CSV importer always assumes default jvm character encoding

fields.description:
While Crowd is optimized to sync to Active Directory, for other LDAP structures Crowd follows a generic algorithm.

The following describes the observed behavior (via LDAP query logging) during sync of a directory of type "Open LDAP (Read Only Posix Schema)":

{code}
1. Search all data on all users:
ou=People,dc=example,dc=com '(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)'

2. Search all data on all groups:
ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com '(cn=*)'

3. Repeat step 2.

4. For each group found, do the following:
	a. Search for all data on that group:
	ou=Groups,dc=example,dc=com '(&(cn=*)(cn=<groupname>))'

	b. Search for all users who have that group's GID number:
	ou=People,dc=example,dc=com '(&(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)(gidNumber=<gidnumber>))'

	c. For all users in that group:
		I. Search for users with that uid:
		ou=People,dc=example,dc=com '(&(objectClass=inetOrgPerson)(uid=<uid>))'
{code}

It seems that from steps 1 and 2, Crowd should have all the information it needs. Step 4 performs a series of nested loops (for each group... for each user... etc), which can take some time for larger LDAP servers.
fields.summary: Optimize LDAP sync behavior for non-AD structures

fields.description:
When we change in Collax a user to "inactive", this state is not reflected in the crowd database.
The proposed workaround is to remove the user from ldap and re-create the user on crowd. The result is two directories of users in one company. Administration, search, migration will become error-prone and is not acceptable for us. After using crowd with LDAP for about 2 yours, we get to our licence-limit of 100, where the active users are about 70 users.  

*Steps to reproduce:*
# install Crowd
# Create new Directory connecting to OpenLDAP using Connector
# try to disable any user sync from OpenLDAP by unchecking the Active checkbox

*Expected Behaviour:*
User will be disactivated

*Actual Behaviour:*
Crowd indicate update is sucessful, but the user remain active
 !screenshot2.png|thumbnail! 


Environment:
Crowd connected to OpenLDAP

*Notes*
This is not reproducible when Crowd is connecting to Microsoft AD
fields.summary: Support changing active status (activating/deactivating) for users in OpenLDAP directories
No way to configure DN subtree matching to be case-insensitive and handle whitespace properly

fields.description:
When using Crowd, Confluence, and JIRA, you can add users to Crowd directly from either JIRA or Confluence.  However, when the user is added in one application, they are not visible to the other application until a sync job is run.

We should add an event that triggers a sync for all consuming applications when a user is added to a Crowd directory.
fields.summary: Force application sync on add user event

fields.description:
Having to run apache behind nginx causes another Single Point of Failure (SPoF), another debugging and support complication.  It would be simpler for environments that standardize on Nginx to have an Nginx Crowd module.  Nginx is currently the #2 most popular webserver in the world (ignoring special-purpose webservers such as Google).[1]

[1] http://vbtechsupport.com/1689/
fields.summary: Crowd authentication support for Nginx

fields.description:
The crowd HTTP authentication library (i.e. the one using REST) sends an IP address when requesting an SSO token. An IPv6 address may have a zone id in the address (e.g. fe80::1%lo0, fe80::21f:5bff:fe33:57c4%en0 on Mac). In fixing CWD-2711 in 2.3.5 and later we remove the zone id before requesting the SSO token. As the address is used in the generation of the token, it means that a SSO token generated from <=2.3.4 is incompatible with one produced from >=2.3.5 when using IPv6 addresses with zone ids.

Example:

JIRA has Crowd 2.3.6.
Confluence has Crowd 2.3.2.

# User logs into JIRA. 
# JIRA sends login request to Crowd server with IP address ::1.
# JIRA logs user in and returns SSO token from Crowd in Cookie.

# User logs into Confluence on same box.
# Confluence sends SSO token to Crowd server with IP address ::1%0.
# Crowd rejects the SSO token because the IP addresses do not match.
# Confluence tells the user of the failure.
fields.summary: Crowd client <=2.3.4 produces SSO tokens that are incompatible with >=2.3.5 on IPv6 addresses with scopes

fields.description:
When the number of users is approaching the license limit, Crowd pops out a warning at the home page of the Crowd Console:
!crowdnulllicense.jpg!
Notice that the warning reads: "You are approaching your user limit of null with xx users". 

This seems to be an issue with the license manager getting the license limit. 

Reproduced on 2.0.7, 2.1.1, 2.3.4, so I believe this affects all released Crowd versions.

h3.Steps to reproduce:
# Install any versions of Crowd
# Get a Crowd license with limits around 50 or 100 users (does not matter, as long as it is not unlimited, but easier to reproduce with lower user limit)
# Put in as many users as possible, until the warning pops up (usually around 46 users, for a 50 user license)
fields.summary: You are approaching your user limit of null with xx users
NotSerializableException from Crowd's query cache

fields.description:
At the moment CrowdService.search() with an entity type of User will query the directories in order and stop once it has enough users to satisfy the maxReturn param. It should return users from all directories properly globally ordered. 

To illustrate, if I had:

DIR 0: ADAM, BEN, ZACHARY
DIR 1: CARL, DAVE

and called CrowdService.search() with a maxReturn of 3 and an offset of 0, I would receive:

\[ADAM, BEN, ZACHARY\]

For my usecase I need to get:

\[ADAM, BEN, CARL\]
fields.summary: Java API for searching for users that returns cross-directory results, correctly sorted

fields.description:
When mod_dav is compiled in Apache as a static module mod_dav.so does not exist under the Apache modules directory.

This therefore either requires a user to create a dummy version (just using touch mod_dav.so) or completely recompile the module as a shared module (which in the case of cPanel is not a straightforward process to maintain).

Creating a dummy version is poor practice as it could lead to confusion and Apache not loading if the mod_dav.so file is attempted to be loaded and the procedure for manually maintaining the shared module is extremely cumbersome and not upgrade-safe (see http://technicalnotebook.com/wiki/display/home/Compile+Atlassian%27s+Crowd+authenticator+on+CentOS+server+with+cPanel down the bottom under Original Procedure for details).

Therefore would it please be possible to add a --skip-deps-check and --skip-httpconf-changes to the compile script, without the dependant modules being referenced the modules configure and compile without issue (as is apparent by creating the dummy files).

Many thanks
Stuart
fields.summary: ./configure script fails when mod_dav is built as a static module

fields.description:
The ./configure script provided for building the Crowd Apache Connector (http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Installing+the+Crowd+Apache+Connector+on+Other+UNIX-Like+Systems) has hardcoded file paths for checking for the apache installation and modules directories.

As Apache is not always installed in these locations the build often fails whereby requiring symbolic links to be created to enable the configuration to complete successfully.

Would it please be possible to add two command line parameters to the ./configure script to enable custom paths to be used without manually having to manage symbolic links on the filesystem.

Regards
Stuart
fields.summary: ./configure script incompatibility with certain apache configurations
